Graphical abstract Bifunctional Palladium (Pd) supported Y-zeolite, with SiO2/Al2O3 ratios 5, 12, 30 and 60, prepared by impregnation method were used for hydroalkylation of benzene. It is found that the reaction condition and catalyst composition influence the hydroalkylation activity and cyclohexylbenzene (CHB) selectivity. CHB selectivity of a hydroalkylation catalyst can be determined by the destiny of the intermediate cyclohexene formed by partial hydrogenation of benzene on the metal site of the catalyst. That is, if the intermediate cyclohexene hydrogenates to cyclohexane on the metal site, the selectivity for CHB decreases whereas, if the intermediate cyclohexene is alkylated with benzene on the acid sites, the selectivity for CHB increases. Thus, there is a requirement of optimum balance of exposed metal and acid sites of the catalyst for enhancing CHB selectivity. At 42.2% of benzene conversion, Pd (0.2wt%)/HY5 (SiO2/Al2O3 =5) catalyst gave a CHB selectivity of 75% in comparison to 70.3% for the best patented catalyst. Furthermore, a kinetic model has been developed for the hydroalkylation of benzene, assuming dissociative, non-competitive addition of hydrogen. Finally, the developed kinetic model along with experimental data was used to study the effect of mole ratio of acid sites to exposed metal sites of Pd/HY catalyst system for hydroalkylation reaction. Based on these results, the ratio of number of acid sites to exposed metal sites can be tuned to maximize CHB yield. Keywords Bi-functional catalyst Metal acid balance Hydroalkylation Kinetic modeling Cyclohexylbenzene 1 Introduction Phenol is an important industrial chemical with numerous applications. It is also the starting material for the synthesis of several important products like phenolic resins, bisphenol A, ε-caprolactam and alkylphenols [1]. Currently more than 90% of the world’s phenol production technology is based on the Hock process and this process is based on alkylation of benzene with propylene to produce cumene followed by oxidation of cumene to cumene hydroperoxide and its cleavage to phenol and acetone [1,2].To operate this process economically, the demand for both the products must be in proportion to their production rate (i.e 1: 1 molar ratio for phenol and acetone). However, the world demand for phenol is growing more rapidly than that of acetone making the process less economical [1–3]. Oxidation of cyclohexylbenzene (CHB) to benzylic hydroperoxide and the cleavage of this hydroperoxide to produce phenol and cyclohexanone, as shown in Fig. 1 can be more attractive route for the production of phenol. Furthermore this alternate route produces more valuable cyclohexanone as a co-product and does not require costlier propylene as raw material [1–3]. However, this alternate route requires the development of efficient catalyst and economical process for the commercial production of CHB, which also has several direct applications like solvent and plasticizer in plastics, coatings and adhesive fields [4]. It is also used as an over charge protecting agent in lithium ion batteries and a base material for LCD derivatives. Furthermore, the co-produced cyclohexanone is a useful intermediate for the manufacture of adipic acid, caprolactam and nylon [5,6]. Dehydrogenation of CHB also offers a cost effective route for the production of biphenyl, and the produced biphenyl is mainly used as a heat transfer fluid and dye carrier in textile industry [7]. In view of the above, the main objective of the present study is to develop an efficient catalyst for the conversion of benzene to cyclohexylbenzene. Owing to CHB applicative potential, numerous attempts have been reported to convert benzene to CHB. In this context, hydroalkylation/alkylation of benzene has been investigated. Typically, CHB is produced by the direct alkylation of benzene and cyclohexene using aluminium chloride or sulphuric acid as catalysts. This direct alkylation route not only uses hazardous acid catalysts such as sulfuric acid and aluminium chloride but also offer low selectivity (around 44%) for CHB [8,9].Considering the environmental hazard associated with the direct alkylation route it is imperative to look for alternative environmental friendly routes. Hydroalkylation of benzene using heterogeneous bifunctional catalyst provides such an alternative route for CHB synthesis [5,10]. Based on literature, hydroalkylation reaction pathway (Fig. 2 ) involves partial hydrogenation of benzene at the metal site to produce cyclohexene which then alkylates with benzene at the acid site to produce CHB. However, formation of by-products like dicyclohexylbenzene (DCHB) and cyclohexane are reported to form during the course of the reaction. Furthermore, under severe conditions, formation of bicyclohexyl by hydrogenation of CHB at the metal site of the catalyst is also reported [5,10]. Thus, several bifunctional catalyst recipes comprising of Pd, Ru, Ni, Co, Pt, Rh, Re, Sn, Zn metal supported on SiO2, Al2O3 and zeolites like MOR, Beta, 13X, MCM-22 have been investigated for hydroalkylation of benzene [5–14]. Fahy et al., studied the hydroalkylation of benzene on four component catalyst system consisting of Nickel, Platinum, Rare earth ions over zeolite 13X and suggested that the addition of rare earth alters the electron transfer to the metal thereby reducing adsorption strength of benzene which in turn helps in hydroalkylation rather than hydrogenation thus improving CHB selectivity [10]. This study also suggested that, addition of small amount of platinum on the catalyst will facilitate the reduction of nickel which in turn favors hydroalkylation at lower temperatures. The best catalyst, 5wt.%Ni/10wt.%Re/0.1wt.%Pt loaded on 13X zeolite showed a selectivity of 70% for CHB at 20% benzene conversion [10] (refer Table 1 , entry 1). Jun et al., studied the hydroalkylation activity in a batch process over palladium supported on Beta zeolite with different Si/Al ratio [5]. Beta zeolite with a low SiO2/Al2O3 ratio showed better activity for hydroalkylation due to higher Brønsted acidity (refer Table 1, entry 2). This concluded that 0.2%Pd/Hβ25 is a promising catalyst for hydroalkylation of benzene and having optimum balance between metal active sites and acidic sites in the catalyst is the key to better selectivity for CHB formation during benzene hydroalkylation. Kralik et al., studied the hydroalkylation activity in a batch reactor over 0.2wt.% of ruthenium loaded on mordenite and beta zeolites [11]. The obtained results demonstrated higher activity of 0.2wt.% Ru/Beta zeolite vis-à-vis 0.2wt.% Ru/Mordenite owing to ease of accessibility of acid sites for hydroalkylation leading to the best catalyst selectivity with the sum of CHB and DCHB which varied from 60 to 40% at benzene conversion of 30 and 80%, respectively (refer Table 1, entry 3). More recently, several researchers have studied the hydroalkylation of phenolic compounds on Pt, Pd doped HY, HBEA and H-Mordenite zeolites [15–17]. In their study, the authors suggested that an optimum metal acid balance is required to achieve highest hydroalkylation activity and selectivity. Their study also suggested that, Pd doped zeolite is more effective catalyst than Pt doped zeolite for the hydroalkylation reaction and among zeolites, 3D pore zeolites like HY are more active and selective for hydroalkylation reaction. However, its utility for benzene hydroalkylation reaction remains unexplored. A summary of benzene hydroalkylation performance for different literature reported catalyst recipes is listed in Table 1. Amongst several catalyst formulation described in Table 1, catalyst 4 (0.3%Ru/0.3%Sn/MCM-22), catalyst 5 (0.3%Pd/MCM-22), and catalyst 7 (0.3%Pd/MCM-49) exhibited superior catalytic performance for benzene hydroalkylation with good selectivity for CHB at reasonably higher benzene conversions. Out of these three, catalyst 5 (0.3%Pd/MCM-22) displayed the best selectivity for CHB (70.3%) at highest benzene conversion of ∼48%. From Table 1, it is evident that most of the catalysts reported in literature suffer from the problems pertaining to low selectivity for CHB, low benzene conversion, use of proprietary zeolite supports, formation of large amounts of impurities and high metal loading (over 0.6wt%) which in turn restricted the commercial application of these catalysts, till date, for benzene hydroalkylation process. Furthermore, several researchers have discussed the importance of metal acid balance of the catalyst for the hydroalkylation reaction however none of the researchers have presented a detailed kinetic study of the effect of relative amounts of acid sites and exposed metal sites of the catalyst on the hydroalkylation reaction [3,5,6,10–12,19]. In view of the above, the present research work focuses on the development of a highly selective, and stable catalyst for converting benzene to CHB. The influence of catalyst properties and the reaction operating conditions were studied on the hydroalkylation activity of the catalyst. In this context, palladium loaded HY zeolite with varied Si/Al ratio were prepared and evaluated for the hydroalkylation activity. Furthermore, a kinetic model has been developed for the hydroalkylation of benzene. The developed kinetic model along with experimental data was used to study the effect acid sites to exposed metal mole ratio of the Pd (0.2wt.%)/HY5 catalyst system. Finally, the obtained experimental and kinetic modelling results are discussed in terms of the support and metal characteristics for maximization of CHB yield. 2 Experimental A series of commercial Y-Zeolite samples from Zeolyst International (CBV300, CBV712, CBV720, CBV 760), with different Si/Al ratio were used as catalyst supports and the structure of the Y-zeolite is shown in Fig. 3 . CBV 300 is a parent Y- Zeolite with SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of 5 and CBV712 (SiO2/Al2O3 =12), CBV720 (SiO2/Al2O3 =30) and CBV 760 (SiO2/Al2O3 =60) were obtained by different degree of dealumination of CBV 300. The following nomenclature is used henceforth to identify the samples: HY5 for catalyst prepared using CBV 300 as support, HY12 for catalyst prepared using CBV 712 as support, HY30 for catalyst prepared using CBV 720 as support and so on. All catalyst supports were prepared by mixing 65wt.% zeolite and 35wt.% alumina binder. All zeolite samples were dried at 393K overnight and the ammonium form of Y zeolites (CBV300 and CBV712) were converted to H form by heating at 823K for 10h before mixing. The mixture was then kneaded into a dough with 5wt.% acetic acid. The dough was then extruded into extrudates having a length of ∼3mm and diameter of 1.5mm, respectively. The extrudates were then dried at 403K overnight and then calcined in oxygen at 823K for 7h. Pd (0.2wt.%)/HY catalysts were prepared by impregnating technique using aqueous solution of palladium nitrate salt as reported elsewhere [12]. After the impregnation excess water was removed by drying the catalysts at 373K overnight and the dried catalysts was once again calcined in oxygen at 823K for 7h. 2.1 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction studies of the catalyst samples were performed using Philips X'pert powder diffractometer system with Cu Kα radiation with a 0.02° step size and 0.4s step time over the range 10°<2θ<50°. The structural acidity was determined by ammonia TPD using Altamira AMI 200 instrument. Prior to TPD studies, the catalyst was activated in helium flow for 2h at 600K. Then the sample was cooled to 373K before the adsorption of ammonia. Subsequently, 6% NH3 in helium (25ml/min) was passed through the sample for 30min followed by treatment in helium flow for 1h. Desorption experiments were carried out in the temperature range of 373–850K at a heating rate of 10K/min [20]. The textural properties of the samples were determined from nitrogen adsorption/desorption data measured over Autosorb-1C (Quantachrome, USA) unit at 77K after degassing samples (<10−3 Torr) at 573K for 4h. The BET specific surface area (SBET) was determined from adsorption data as per the ASTM Method 4365, applicable for microporous solids. The total pore volume, Vt, was estimated from the amount of N2 adsorbed at a relative pressure of 0.95. The external surface area, micropore area, and micropore volume were estimated by employing the t-plot method [21]. Palladium metal dispersion of the catalyst was measured before and after the reaction using H2 chemisorption performed using ASAP 2020 (Micromeritics, USA). Typically, 1g of catalyst was dried in flowing helium at 523K for 1h followed by evacuation at 323K for 1h. The samples were reduced in hydrogen at 673K for 1h, cooled down in hydrogen to 473K, and evacuated for 1h at this temperature. Subsequently the sample was cooled down to room temperature. At 313K the first isotherm was taken. After the first isotherm was measured, the sample was evacuated at 313K for 1h and the second isotherm was obtained. The H/Pdtotal ratios are based on the adsorbed amounts of H2 determined with first isotherm by adopting extrapolation method. The H/Pdstrong ratios are calculated by subtracting the ratios obtained with the second isotherms from the H/Pdtotal ratios. The dispersion was calculated assuming a stoichiometry of adsorption of H2 to be 2 [22]. Concentration of the surface metal atoms was also determined from the metal dispersion data. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was used to determine the particle size and shape of the palladium nanoparticles supported on Y zeolite. Sample for TEM analysis was prepared by suspending the finely grinded catalyst in solvent by ultrasonification for 1h and an aliquot of this suspension was deposited onto a carbon coated copper grid which was then allowed to dry slowly at room temperature. TEM images of all the Pd/HY catalysts were obtained using JEOL JEM-2010 transmission electron microscope operated at 200kV. Furthermore, the detailed characterization of acidity using Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), framework Si/Al ratio and total Al content using ICP for the commercial Y zeolites used in this study are reported elsewhere [23–26]. 2.2 Hydroalkylation of benzene Benzene hydroalkylation reaction was carried out in a bench-scale unit as depicted in Fig. 4 . The unit is equipped with a stainless steel fixed bed reactor of length 47cm and internal diameter of 1.1cm with a thermowell for measurement of the catalyst bed temperature. Catalyst was placed in the reactor so as to have minimum temperature gradient. Typically, about 5g of catalyst extrudates were loaded in the reactor and during the loading process, the catalyst was divided into five batches. Following each batch of the catalyst, 80–120mesh sand was packed into the void spaces of the catalyst bed, thus ensuring the uniformity of gas/liquid flow distribution. For the activity tests, benzene and hydrogen in 1:1mole ratio are used as feed and catalyst was dried under N2 flow over night at 423K followed by reduction at atmospheric pressure under 50ml/min of H2 at 573K for 5h. After reduction, the reactor was cooled to the desired temperature and then pressurized to the operating pressure and benzene was pumped using a high performance liquid chromatography pump (HPLC pump). The steady state products were collected and analyzed by employing GC technique (Agilent 6890N) gas chromatograph analyzer equipped with a FID and a DB-Petro column (100m×250μm×0.5μm nominal). Conversion and CHB selectivity are defined as follows: C o n v e r s i o n ( % ) ( ( B e n z e n e ) f e e d − ( B e n z e n e ) p r o d u c t ) * 100 ( B e n z e n e ) f e e d C H B s e l e c t i v i t y ( % ) ( ( C H B ) p r o d u c t ) * 100 C o n v e r s i o n Here, (Benzene)feed and (Benzene)product are the concentrations of benzene in the feed and reactor effluent stream respectively, and (CHB) product is the concentration of CHB in the reactor effluent stream. All the experiments were performed with utmost care and only runs where mass balance in the range of 98-103 98–103%, were considered for data analysis. 3 Results and discussion Influence of HY support properties on hydroalkylation reaction parameters has been investigated and the obtained results are discussed in the following sections. 3.1 Textural and chemical properties of catalysts The textural properties of the catalyst samples were determined from nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherm measurement data shown in Fig. 5 . Pd/HY5, the parent Y- Zeolite did not exhibit any hysteresis in the isotherm, whereas, Pd/HY12, Pd/HY30, and Pd/HY60 showed hysteresis in their isotherm. This can be attributed to the creation of mesopores due to the collapse of some portion of the zeolite crystal during the dealumination process of the support [27]. The estimated chemical composition and textural properties of the catalyst samples are compiled in Table 2 . The BET surface area for these catalysts was in the range of 521–615m2/g with Pd/HY60 showing the highest followed by Pd/HY30, Pd/HY12, and Pd/HY5. Similar trends were seen in the case of external surface area and pore volume (refer Table 2). Increased external surface area and pore volume of Pd/HY12, Pd/HY30 and Pd/HY60 compared to Pd/HY5 can be attributed to the pore condensation of nitrogen in mesopores created during the dealumination process of the support. XRD patterns for all the samples are presented in Fig. 6 . The percentage crystallinity of the samples decreased according to the sequence Pd/HY5> Pd/HY12> Pd/HY30> Pd/HY60, respectively. NH3 TPD profiles for different Pd/HY catalysts are shown in Fig. 7 . The measured NH3 desorption patterns for all the catalyst showed two overlapping peaks and the obtained desorption chromatograms were very much similar to the chromatograms reported elsewhere for Y zeolites [28]. Typically, high temperature peak corresponds to desorption of NH3 from strong acid sites. On the other hand, the low-temperature peak can be due to a number of reasons: (a) desorption of weakly adsorbed NH3 on weak acid sites or non-acidic site, (b) weak Brönsted acid sites, (c) Lewis sites, silanol groups and (d) formation of NH4 +(NH3)n (n≥1) groups as mentioned elsewhere [26,28]. Total acid site concentration and the concentration of weak and strong acid sites obtained from de-convolution of the NH3 TPD data of different Pd/HY catalysts are listed in Table 3 . Typically, catalyst acidity decreased according to the sequence Pd/HY5> Pd/HY12> Pd/HY30> Pd/HY60. Interestingly, desorption pattern for Pd/HY5 showed the maximum peak temperature at about 630K and the desorption pattern for Pd/HY12, Pd/HY30 and Pd/Pd/HY60 showed slightly higher maximum peak temperature at about 670K, thus indicating the fact that the dealumination of Y zeolite decreases the total number of acid site and increases the strength of acid sites as mentioned elsewhere [26–29]. Brönsted and Lewis sites of all the zeolites used in the present study were estimated earlier using Pyridine FTIR by Keller et al. and the same were utilized to determine the Brönsted and Lewis sites of the final catalysts based on the Y zeolite content of the catalyst and the obtained results are shown in Table 3 [26]. Palladium metal dispersion of all the catalysts was measured using H2 chemisorption data and the metal dispersion of all the catalysts varied in the range of 21–23% as shown in Table 2 and the concentration of the surface metal atoms of all the catalyst varied in the range of 394–432μmol Pds/g cat. Metal dispersion of the used catalysts was also measured after calcining the catalysts in oxygen and all the catalyst retained their metal dispersion after the reaction. Furthermore, palladium(Pd) contents of the fresh and calcined used catalyst samples were estimated by means of inductively coupled plasma (ICP) technique (Perkin Elmer, Model: Optima 2000), the metal content of fresh and used catalyst were found to be 0.197 and 0.195wt%, respectively. Mole ratio of acid sites to exposed metal sites of all the catalyst was obtained from the ratio of concentration of strong acid sites from NH3 TPD data and the concentration of the surface metal atoms from the H2 chemisorption data. TEM images of all the four Palladium loaded HY catalysts are shown in Fig. 8 . For all the catalysts, the Palladium nanoparticle are well distributed on the catalyst support and most of them are found to have tetrahedral shape with a size range of 2–8nm. Palladium particle size distribution (PSD) of Pd (0.2wt.%)/HY5 catalyst is shown in Fig. 9 and according to the PSD most of the palladium particles on Pd (0.2wt.%)/HY5 catalyst are in the range of 2–5nm. Average Palladium crystallite size determined from dispersion data come out to be around 5.0nm for all the catalyst and the correlation used to determine Pd average particle size d (nm) using metal dispersion data D is d(nm)=1.13/D [30]. Furthermore, the particle size of the Palladium particles are larger than the pore size of the Y zeolite (0.74nm), thus concluding the fact that the, Palladium nanoparticles are located on the external surface of the catalyst support. 3.2 Activity of different Pd/HY catalysts for benzene hydroalkylation To investigate the catalytic activity, hydroalkylation of benzene was performed in a fixed bed reactor at the reaction conditions of P=20–35bar; T=383–443K, H2/C6H6 mole ratio of 1–4 and WHSV=0.3–2h−1 respectively. All the experiments were carried out with utmost care and only runs with mass balance in the range of 97–103%, were considered for data analysis. Typically, during hydroalkylation, benzene is partially hydrogenated to cyclohexene along with little amount of cyclohexane over the metal sites of the catalyst. Cyclohexene reacts with benzene on the acid sites of the catalyst to form the main product CHB. By-product like DCHB can also from due to the alkylation of cyclohexene with CHB on the acid sites of the catalyst as shown in Fig. 2. Catalytic performance of all the Pd (0.2wt.%)/HY catalysts were compared at same benzene conversion and the observed results are shown in Table 4 . Interestingly, Pd/HY5 showed good activity for benzene hydroalkylation followed by Pd/HY12, Pd/HY30 and Pd/HY60. Pd/HY12 gave marginally lower benzene conversion as compared to Pd/HY5 at same WHSV whereas, on Pd/HY30 and Pd/HY60 catalyst, the WHSV required to achieve similar conversion as that of Pd/HY5 were 0.4 (h−1) and 0.3 (h−1) respectively. Lower WHSV’s on these catalysts further lead to lower yield of CHB due to formation of side products like cyclohexane and DCHB. Since all the above catalyst had similar metal dispersion at identical metal loading, obtained activity results over these catalysts can be attributed to the acidity of the catalyst. Furthermore, good activity of Pd (0.2wt.%)/HY5 for benzene hydroalkylation with excellent selectivity for CHB vis-à-vis literature reported hydroalkylation catalysts in spite of having lower noble metal loading of 0.2wt% can be attributed to higher acidity coupled with hydrogen spillover effect, wherein, along with metal centres, the acid sites of support also play role in aromatics hydrogenation favoring the hydrogenation of benzene as reported elsewhere [5,10,11,31–34]. Pd/HY5 catalyst provided more number of acid sites for the alkylation reaction and hence the cyclohexene formed during the reaction could immediately alkylate with benzene on the acid site resulting in higher yield for CHB. Based on the above results, Pd/HY5 is selected to evaluate the effect of different operating conditions on the activity and selectivity of the catalyst. 3.2.1 Effect of WHSV The effect of contact time (1/WHSV) on the catalytic performance of Pd/HY5 for the hydroalkylation of benzene to CHB was studied by varying the WHSV from 0.3 to 2h−1, and the results are shown in Fig. 10 . It was found that the conversion of benzene increased with increase in contact time, but the selectivity for CHB decreased due to the formation of higher amounts of cyclohexane and DCHB due to further hydrogenation of cyclohexene and alkylation of CHB with benzene respectively at higher contact times [11]. From the above results, it is evident that, contact time is an important factor for selective production of CHB. From Fig. 10 it is also evident that, beyond benzene conversion of around 40% there is drop in selectivity of CHB due to the formation of by-products and hence the benzene conversion has to be limited to around 40%, in order to produce CHB with high selectivity. Using Pd/HY5 catalyst, selectivity of CHB was around 77% at a benzene conversion of 42% at a contact time of 2h (WHSV=0.5h−1) and this is the best possible selectivity for CHB at considerably good benzene conversion for the present catalyst system. Hence this value of WHSV was used to evaluate the catalyst performance at different process variables. Beyond this value of contact time there is an increase in the formation of DCHB leading to decrease in selectivity for CHB. At identical benzene conversion of 48%, the present catalyst gave a CHB selectivity of 75% at a contact time of 2.3h in comparison to 70.3% for the best literature reported catalyst (see catalyst 5 of Table 1). 3.2.2 Effect of hydrogen pressure The effect of hydrogen pressure on the catalytic performance of Pd/HY5 for the hydroalkylation of benzene is shown in Fig. 11 . Benzene conversion linearly increased with increase in hydrogen pressure, which indicates that hydrogen pressure has significant effect on hydrogenation activity. When the hydrogen pressure increased from 20 to 35bar, the benzene conversion increased from 42% to 60% and the selectivity for CHB decreased from 77% to 55%. The results indicated that high hydrogen pressure increased the adsorption of hydrogen on the catalyst surface leading to further hydrogenation of benzene to form cyclohexane leading to the drop in selectivity for CHB. Based on the obtained results, pressure levels of 20–25bar is found to be the best. At pressure lower than 20bar conversion of benzene is low, whereas at higher pressure total hydrogenation of benzene is more favorable. Furthermore, continuous increase in benzene conversion with hydrogen pressure indicate the fact that, hydrogen and benzene are adsorbed on different types of sites (non-competitive adsorption) and that the reaction occurs simultaneously on metal surface and on acid sites in the interface region as reported elsewhere [5,12,33,35,36]. 3.2.3 Effect of hydrogen to benzene mole ratio The effect of H2/Benzene mole ratio on the catalytic performance of Pd/HY5 for the hydroalkylation of benzene is shown in Fig. 12 . When the H2/Benzene mole ratio was increased from 1 to 4, the benzene conversion increased from 42% to 49%, and the selectivity for CHB decreased from 77% to 61%. The results indicated that as H2/C6H6 mole ratio is increased, the selectivity for CHB decreases due to the formation of more by-products. The results showed that the H2/Benzene mole ratio is an important factor for the selective formation of CHB and H2/C6H6 mole ratio of around 1 is found to be the best. Any decrease in this value may promote catalyst deactivation and increase in H2/C6H6 mole ratio beyond 1, will promote the formation of more by-products [12]. 3.2.4 Effect of temperature The effect of reaction temperature on the catalytic performance of Pd/HY5 for the hydroalkylation of benzene to CHB was studied by varying the temperature from 383 to 443K, and the results are shown in Fig. 13 . The reaction temperature strongly effects the reaction route and hence the product distribution. It was found that the conversion of benzene increased with an increase in reaction temperature, due to higher rate of hydrogenation reaction at higher temperature but the selectivity for CHB decreased due to the formation of higher amounts of cyclohexane and DCHB. Beyond 423K, complete hydrogenation of benzene and alkylation of CHB becomes the predominant route leading to formation of higher amounts of bi-products. From the above results it turns out that the optimum temperature for the best possible CHB selectivity at reasonably good benzene conversions is around 423K. 3.2.5 Effect of time on stream (TOS) Pd/HY5 catalyst stability was examined at 20bar, 1 WHSV, 423K and H2/C6H6 mole ratio of 1 to investigate its deactivation. In this context, the hydroalkylation of benzene was performed for over 100h after attaining steady state and the benzene conversion and CHB selectivity was analysed at regular intervals. Fig. 14 shows the effect of time on stream on benzene conversion under steady state condition. Conversion of benzene dropped only 2% with negligible change in CHB selectivity during 120h of on stream operation after achieving steady state. Thus, results shown in Fig. 14 confirmed almost no loss in catalyst activity during the on-stream operation. Furthermore, used catalyst samples were evaluated at reaction condition identical to that of fresh catalyst (TOS study) and the loss in activity was 2% with respect to benzene conversion as compared to fresh catalyst. During similar study by Fahy et al. for the hydroalkylation of benzene on Pt/Ni/Re-13X, benzene conversion decreased by almost 10% during the 120h of on stream operation [10]. Similarly, for the hydroalkylation of benzene and ethylbenzene on Ru/Ni/Beta, Borodina et al. reported a drop in conversion of around 15% during 100h of on stream operation after achieving steady state [12]. 4 Kinetic model development A kinetic model for the hydroalkylation of benzene on Pd/HY5 catalyst was also discussed based on the product distribution obtained. The developed kinetic model is simple with few reaction steps and kinetic parameters and detailed enough for analysis of the key features of the benzene hydroalkylation reaction. The detailed procedure for the development of the kinetic model is discussed below: 4.1 Reaction and adsorption steps The kinetic model was based on the surface reaction mechanism proposed earlier by Rahaman et al. for the hydrogenation of aromatics over palladium loaded catalyst [30,34,35]. The mechanism consists of series of adsorption, reaction and desorption steps. It is assumed that, benzene and hydrogen are non-competitively adsorbed on the active site of the catalyst with benzene adsorbing on the acid sites of the catalyst and hydrogen adsorbing on the metal sites of the catalyst [30,32,34,35]. The dissociatively adsorbed hydrogen molecules migrates to the interfacial region via hydrogen spillover and the reaction occurs simultaneously on both metal and acid sites of the catalyst in the interface region [35,36]. The intermediate cyclohexene has a tendency to desorb from the catalytic surface as it is very unstable in the adsorbed form due to loss of resonance [38]. The desorbed cyclohexene alkylates with benzene on the acid sites of the catalyst to from CHB. By-product DCHB can also from due to the alkylation of cyclohexene with CHB on the acid sites of the catalyst. 4.1.1 Adsorption of hydrogen and benzene on metal and acid sites of the catalyst respectively H 2 + 2 Z m ↔ K a 1 2 H * Z m B + Z ↔ K a 2 B * Z 4.1.2 Surface reaction over the metal and acid sites of the catalyst B * Z + H − Z m ↔ K 1 B 1 * Z + Z m B 1 * Z + H − Z m → K 2 B 2 * Z + Z m B 2 * Z + H − Z m ↔ K 3 B 3 * Z + Z m B 3 * Z + H − Z m ↔ K 4 B 4 * Z + Z m B 4 * Z + H − Z m ↔ K 5 B 5 * Z + Z m B 5 * Z + H − Z m ↔ K 6 C 6 H 12 * Z + Z m B * Z + C 6 H 10 → k 7 C 12 H 16 * Z C 12 H 16 * Z + C 6 H 10 → k 8 C 18 H 26 * Z 4.1.3 Desorption of hydrocarbons from the acid and metal sites of the catalyst C 6 H 12 * Z ↔ 1 / K a 3 C 6 H 12 + Z C 12 H 16 * Z ↔ 1 / K a 4 C 12 H 16 + Z C 18 H 26 * Z ↔ 1 / K a 5 C 18 H 26 + Z Here, Z denotes the acid sites of the catalyst, Zm denotes the metal sites of the catalyst and the first six steps of the surface reaction denote the sequential addition of adsorbed hydrogen to the benzene nucleus with Bi being the intermediate obtained after adding i number of hydrogen atoms to benzene. B*Z, C6H12*Z, C12H16*Z and C18H26*Z are adsorbed forms of benzene, cyclohexane, CHB and DCHB on acid sites of the catalyst respectively and H*Zm, is the adsorbed forms of hydrogen atom on the metal sites of the catalyst. Ka1 and Ka2 are the equilibrium constants for the adsorption of benzene and hydrogen on acid and metal sites of the catalyst respectively, Ka3, Ka4 and Ka5 are equilibrium constants for adsorption of cyclohexane, CHB and DCHB respectively. 4.2 Rate equations Based on the study reported earlier, the initial destabilization of the benzene resonance is considered to the rate limiting step for the hydrogenation of benzene and the rates of the hydrocarbon adsorption and desorption are assumed to be much faster than the rates of the hydrocarbon transformation and the same considered for the development of rate equations [30,35,37]. Langmuir–Hinshelwood (LH) approach was followed to derive the equations for the rates of the reaction steps. For instance, the rate equation for the hydrogenation of benzene is given below: r2 =k2* Ka1* Ka2 * CB* CH2* Zm* Z Where r2 is the net rate of reaction step 2, k2 is the rate constant for the hydrogenation of benzene, CB is the concentration of benzene, CH2 is the concentration of hydrogen. Singh et al., studied the liquid phase hydrogenation of benzene on Pt catalyst and reported that, liquid phase hydrogen concentration rather than hydrogen partial pressure was better choice for the reaction rate expression [36]. In the present work, concentration of hydrogen in liquid phase was assumed to be in equilibrium with concentration of hydrogen in the gas phase [37]. Zm and Z are the steady-state fraction of the vacant metal and acid sites of the catalyst respectively and are defined by Z m = 1 1 + Ka 1 * C H 2 Z = 1 1 + Ka 2 * C B + Ka 3 * C CH + Ka 4 * C CHB + Ka 5 * C DCHB Where CB, CCH, CCHB and CDCHB are the concentrations of benzene, cyclohexane, CHB and DCHB respectively. The kinetic model was represented as a set of 5 equations describing the rates of transformation of 5 components in 13 reaction steps: R i = ∑ s = 1 13 γ i s * r s ( 1 ≤ i ≤ 5 ) Where Ri is the rate of transformation of the component i (molg−1 h−1), γis is the stoichiometric coefficient of the component i in the reaction step s and rs is the rate of the reaction step s. For kinetic modelling, the plug flow reactor model shown below was used. d W i d Γ = R i M i ( 1 ≤ i ≤ 5 ) Where Wi is the weight fraction of the component i in the reaction mixture, Γ is the contact time (h) and Mi is the molecular weight of component i (gmol−1). Contact time is defined as the ratio between the catalyst weight (W) and the mass flow rate of the feed (m), i.e., Γ=W/m=WHSV−1, where WHSV is the weight hour space velocity (h−1). The above approach for the generation of rate expression and kinetic model was reported earlier by several researchers [39–43]. 4.3 Estimation of the kinetic parameters and TOF’s The presence of internal mass transfer limitations was investigated by carrying out hydroalkylation reaction on catalyst extrudates with pellet diameters of 0.8, 1.5 and 1.7mm. Under identical experimental conditions, conversion and selectivity results were similar for all three extrudates and the differences were well within the limits of experimental error. Thus confirming absence of internal mass transfer limitations. While, the presence of external mass transfer limitations was investigated by systematically increasing both the feed mass flow rate and catalyst loading (5 and 10g), maintaining same WHSV and reaction conditions. The absence of external mass transfer limitations was confirmed as the conversion and selectivity results were similar for both the experiments. In absence of internal and external mass transfer limitation, the experimental results are exclusively governed by the underlying surface reactions. Thus, the developed plug flow reactor model for benzene hydroalkylation was modeled assuming the reactor to be a one dimensional isothermal reactor. Owing to its small bed length overall pressure drop was assumed to be negligible. Reaction rate constants were estimated using MATLAB's sequential quadratic programming function, minimizing the sum of squared differences between the simulated and experimental results. While, the ordinary differential equation for the concentration profile across the reaction bed at different WHSV values was solved using MATLAB ode15s function (a variable order solver and makes use of backward differentiation formula) with an initial set of rate constants. The rate constants were then varied until the objective function was minimized. The rate constants thus obtained are reported in Table 5 . With the given set of assumptions, there is good agreement between the experimental and simulated results as shown in Fig. 15 . Analysis of the experimental and kinetic modelling data has confirmed that, during hydroalkylation, benzene is partially hydrogenated to cyclohexene along with little amount of cyclohexane over the active sites of the catalyst. Cyclohexene reacts with benzene on the acid sites of the catalyst to form the main product CHB. Alkylation of cyclohexene with CHB on the acid sites of the catalyst results in the formation of DCHB. For the present catalyst system, the surface reaction rate constant for the hydrogenation of benzene is 0.039molg−1 h−1 and the surface reaction rate constant for the hydroalkylation of benzene and CHB are 5.61molg−1 h−1 and 3.51molg−1 h−1 respectively. The values of the equilibrium constants for adsorption of hydrogen on metal site (Ka1) and benzene on the acid site (Ka2) were also estimated in the above study and the value of Ka1 and Ka2 are 0.127bar−1 and 0.21bar−1 respectively and the values of the equilibrium constants for the desorption of cyclohexane (1/Ka3), CHB (1/Ka4) and DCHB (1/Ka5) are 0.51bar, 0.66bar, and 0.47bar respectively. Table 5 summarizes the values of the rate constants for the different reaction involved in the hydroalkylation of benzene and these values demonstrate that hydrogenation of benzene on metal sites is the slowest step and benzene hydroalkylation of over acid sites is around 145 times fastest than the benzene hydrogenation step and hence the formed cyclohexene was able to quickly alkylate with benzene on acid sites leading to high selectivity for CHB. Turnover frequencies (TOFs) for the hydrogenation and alkylation reaction were estimated from reaction rate constant using the concentration of the surface metal atoms from H2 chemisorption data and the concentration of strong acid sites from NH3 TPD data respectively and the same are reported in reported in Table 5. The obtained TOF value for the hydrogenation of benzene are in line with the previously reported values [37]. 4.4 Impact of relative concentration of acid sites and exposed metal sites To demonstrate the importance of metal acid balance on the hydroalkylation of benzene over Pd/HY5 catalyst, simulation were carried out using the developed kinetic model at different acid/metal molar ratio by systematically varying the number of acid sites, maintaining constant number of metal sites and the obtained results along with the previously obtained experimental results are shown in Fig. 16 . Acid/metal mole ratio of Pd/HY60, Pd/HY30, Pd/HY12 and Pd/HY5 obtained from the ratio of concentration of strong acid sites from NH3 TPD data and the concentration of the surface metal atoms from the H2 chemisorption data were 0.3, 0.4, 0.5 and 1 respectively. When the acid/metal mole ratio was increased from 0.125 to 1.75, the CHB yield increased from 11.1% to 35%. As seen in Fig. 16, there is no significant increase in CHB yield beyond acid/metal mole ratio of around 0.5, indicative of the fact that beyond this point metal sites become the rate limiting owing to the limited number of metal sites available for the formation of the alkylation agent cyclohexene. This is being the reason for the similar activity of Pd (0.2wt.%)/HY5 and Pd(0.2wt.%)/HY12 in spite of having considerable acidity difference. Similar experimental results were reported by Jun et al., where in the author have increased the metal loading from 0.1 to 0.3wt% on H-Beta zeolite and observed that the CHB yield increases initially and becomes stable beyond the metal loading of 0.25wt% [5]. The possible reason for these results are clearly explained in the present work using experimental and simulation study in terms of kinetic parameters and TOFs. The above results also indicate the fact that, proper balance between metal and acid sites is very important factor for highly active and selective hydroalkylation catalyst and relative concentration of acid sites and exposed metal sites can be tuned to maximize the selectivity for CHB. 5 Conclusion Hydroalkylation of benzene was carried out in a fixed bed reactor using different palladium loaded HY zeolites as supports. Among all the tested catalysts, Pd (0.2wt%)/HY5 proved to be most active, selective and stable catalyst for the hydroalkylation of benzene. Based on the obtained results, it is evident that the acidity and proper balance between the active metal sites and the acid sites of the catalyst is vital for the activity and the selectivity of the hydroalkylation catalyst. The reaction operating conditions for the best possible CHB selectivity at reasonably good benzene conversions are 423K, 20bar, 0.5 WHSV and H2/C6H6 mole ratio of 1. At these operating conditions the selectivity for CHB was 77% at 42% benzene conversion and in spite of having lower metal loading, the results obtained over this catalyst was very much at par with the recently patented catalysts and superior to the open literature catalysts. Furthermore, analysis of the experimental and kinetic modelling data has confirmed that, on 0.2wt.% Pd loaded HY5 catalyst, hydroalkylation reaction is around 145 times faster than the hydrogenation reaction and hence the intermediate cyclohexene was quickly alkylation with benzene on the acid sites of the catalyst leading to higher CHB yields. In view of the obtained results, Pd (0.2wt.%)/HY5 is envisaged to offer excellent platform to develop cost effective process for the production of CHB and the produced CHB can be easily converted to phenol and cyclohexanone using the oxidation and cleavage steps of the well-established Hock process. coredata.dc:description: Bifunctional Palladium (Pd) supported Y-zeolite, with SiO2/Al2O3 ratios 5, 12, 30 and 60, prepared by impregnation method were used for hydroalkylation of benzene. It is found that the reaction condition and catalyst composition influence the hydroalkylation activity and cyclohexylbenzene (CHB) selectivity. CHB selectivity of a hydroalkylation catalyst can be determined by the destiny of the intermediate cyclohexene formed by partial hydrogenation of benzene on the metal site of the catalyst. That is, if the intermediate cyclohexene hydrogenates to cyclohexane on the metal site, the selectivity for CHB decreases whereas, if the intermediate cyclohexene is alkylated with benzene on the acid sites, the selectivity for CHB increases. Thus, there is a requirement of optimum balance of exposed metal and acid sites of the catalyst for enhancing CHB selectivity. At 42.2% of benzene conversion, Pd (0.2wt%)/HY5 (SiO2/Al2O3 =5) catalyst gave a CHB selectivity of 75% in comparison to 70.3% for the best patented catalyst. Furthermore, a kinetic model has been developed for the hydroalkylation of benzene, assuming dissociative, non-competitive addition of hydrogen. Finally, the developed kinetic model along with experimental data was used to study the effect of mole ratio of acid sites to exposed metal sites of Pd/HY catalyst system for hydroalkylation reaction. Based on these results, the ratio of number of acid sites to exposed metal sites can be tuned to maximize CHB yield.
coredata.dc:title: Selective hydroalkylation of benzene over palladium supported Y-Zeolite: Effect of metal acid balance
